body.div:
May 17, 1916 My dear Mrs. Aldis:
I have just received your letter of May 14th. I am very sorry to hear of Mr.Lathrop’s death. I never met him, but Mrs. Lathrop was so very kind as to ask me to stay there at the time of Harriet’s dinner, and I had a letter from her after my recent visit in Chicago telling me of hers and her husband’s illness, but she spoke so hopefully of their both being better, that of course it never occurred to me that he was seriously ill.
I quite understand that it will be impossible for you to give our plays at the end of June, as we arranged, but if you can do it in the early Autumn, I think that it would be quite perfect for me. August would not be very good, as I do not move up to the country until the middle of July, and it would be rather difficult to get down again and out to you so soon. Could we not make it middle or end-September? If that suits you?
I am delighted that you are coming back here next week. Can you not dine with me Sunday night? And I will get Fletcher and one or two other people who are interested in our work. Boston is not much in either the poetical or the dramatic line, and I am afraid that I cannot give you as delightful a time as you gave me. However, as I am a selfish person, I shan’t really care very much, because it will be such a pleasure to me to see you.
On reading over your letter I think it must be this very Friday that you are coming, namely, the day after tomorrow, so I shall consider Sunday an engagement, and shall telephone you Friday
night in the hope of clinching it.
I am sending you a copy of our Anthology. You should have had it before, only the publication was delayed. I trust, however, that it is on sale in Chicago. But Houghton-Mifflin are so careless about the commercial side of their books that it strikes me as quite likely that they have not sent them out to McClurg’s.
I am writing to Margaret Anderson by this mail, telling her that I have asked you to review it for us. I know she will be quite delighted to have you do it, because she asked me when I was in Chicago if there was anyone I could suggest.
Until Friday, then. Believe me, Sincerely yours,
